journey.title: Engineering Manager Interview Prep
journey.description: Master behavioral interviews for engineering leadership roles. Build compelling stories showcasing people leadership, team execution, and strategic impact.

step0_config.title: Customize Your Prep
step0_config.description: Tailor this journey to your level, target company, and key competencies

target_signals.label: Priority Competencies
target_signals.description: Select the signals most important for your target EM role

story_slots.title: Managing Underperformance / Low Performer
story_slots.description: A time when you had to address significant underperformance in a direct report and improve their trajectory.
tips: Show empathy and genuine desire to help them improve
Explain your diagnostic approach - what's really going on?
Describe specific feedback and coaching you provided
Share the outcome - did they improve or did you make a tough call?
Demonstrate learnings about yourself as a manager

story_slots.title: Navigating Team Conflict
story_slots.description: A significant conflict between team members, or between your team and another group, that you had to resolve.
tips: Show emotional intelligence in handling tensions
Explain how you got to root cause vs. symptoms
Demonstrate active listening and perspective-taking
Share how you helped both sides move forward
Highlight what this taught you about team dynamics

story_slots.title: Hiring / Promotion / Termination Decision
story_slots.description: A critical people decision (hiring, promoting, or letting someone go) and your reasoning.
tips: Show rigorous decision-making process
Explain how you gathered diverse perspectives
Be specific about selection criteria
Share how you communicated the decision
Reflect on what happened after and lessons learned

story_slots.title: Turning Around a Struggling Team
story_slots.description: A time when you inherited or took over a team with low morale, poor execution, or quality issues and improved them.
tips: Start with your diagnosis - what was actually broken?
Show multiple levers you pulled (staffing, process, clarity, coaching)
Include specific metrics or evidence of improvement
Share how you built trust and psychological safety
Discuss how you balanced quick wins with long-term changes

story_slots.title: Cross-Functional Initiative with Resistance
story_slots.description: Leading or influencing an initiative that required working across organizations or overcoming resistance.
tips: Explain why there was resistance and from whom
Show how you built coalition and alignment
Demonstrate stakeholder management and influence
Share how you kept teams motivated despite obstacles
Highlight the business impact of the initiative

story_slots.title: Scaling Team / Rapid Growth
story_slots.description: A time when your team grew rapidly or you had to onboard many new people simultaneously.
tips: Describe how you maintained culture during growth
Show how you scaled processes and systems
Discuss how you ramped new team members
Share metrics on retention and performance
Highlight what was different from managing a stable team

story_slots.title: Your Own Learning / Growth as a Manager
story_slots.description: A time when you realized you had a blindspot or needed to grow as a leader, and what you did about it.
tips: Show genuine self-awareness and humility
Describe the feedback or trigger that made you aware
Share specific actions you took to develop
Include both the struggle and the progress
Reflect on how this changed your leadership approach

story_slots.title: Customer-Centric or Product-Focused Decision
story_slots.description: A time when you led your team to make a decision that prioritized customer/product value, even if harder.
tips: Show your understanding of customer needs
Explain the trade-offs and what you prioritized
Share how you got your team aligned on the decision
Highlight the business outcomes
Reflect on what this taught you about product thinking

situation: How big was the team and what was your role?
Who were the key stakeholders involved?
What was the business or team challenge?
problem: What made this genuinely difficult to handle?
What were the conflicting pressures or trade-offs?
What was at stake for the team, org, or business?
What was uncertain or ambiguous about the situation?
actions: What 3-5 key actions did you take?
How did you involve and get buy-in from your team?
What conversations or coaching did you provide?
How did you make the final decision or recommendation?
results: Can you quantify the impact? (team morale, retention, velocity, quality, etc.)
What feedback did you get from your team and peers?
How did this affect your credibility or authority?
What improved as a result of your leadership?
coda: What did you learn about yourself as a leader?
What would you do differently now?
How has this shaped your management philosophy?
What broader lessons apply to other situations?
How do you see this experience informing your future leadership?

follow_up_question_templates: How did your team react to your decision?
What would you do differently in this situation today?
How did you handle dissent or disagreement?
What was the hardest part of this for you?
How did you ensure psychological safety during this?
What metrics did you track to measure success?
How did you develop or coach individuals through this?
What did you learn about your own leadership?
How did this affect retention on your team?
What would your team members say about your leadership in this moment?

quick_prep.name: Quick Prep (3 Stories, 40 min)
quick_prep.description: Cover core EM competencies for initial interviews

standard_em.name: Standard EM Prep (5 Stories, 75-90 min)
standard_em.description: Comprehensive coverage for typical EM interviews

senior_em.name: Senior EM Prep (8 Stories, 120-150 min)
senior_em.description: Full spectrum for senior manager and director-level roles
